repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
There is currently no global option to define the default border style for floating windows. This leads to repetitive code when developers need consistent styling across multiple floating windows.

Solution:
Introduce a global option winborder to specify the default border style for floating windows. When a floating window is created without explicitly specifying a border style, the value of the winborder option will be used. This simplifies configuration and ensures consistency in floating window appearance.



Fix #20202

comment_data.body: if it only support certain values why not directly make this an enum?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -7759,6 +7759,15 @@ vim.o.winbl = vim.o.winblend
 vim.wo.winblend = vim.o.winblend
 vim.wo.winbl = vim.wo.winblend
 
+--- Configures the border style of floating windows, border values only
+--- support string type which defined in `nvim_open_win()`.
+---
+--- @type string

comment_data.body: if the abbreviations are hard to remember they are pretty useless, aren't they? do we actually need an abbreviation for this?

~~also need a single "validation" tests that runs through all the valid values.~~

This also somewhat mitigates the fact that the values are repeated at `p_winbd_values` and [`parse_border_style`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ac7e0ff32ff18be69e2469ff7fc66370be20a6e1/src/nvim/api/win_config.c#L933-L945), though ideally they would use one source of truth.

```lua
    it('#winborder validation', function()
      command('set winborder=single')
      command('set winborder=double')
      command('set winborder=...')
    end)
It's tested in `gen_opt_test.vim`
`wbd` should be sounds good ?
How is that less hard to remember than `winbd`?
Still wrong place. This is the `number options` section. It should be in the `Nvim-only options` section.

@@ -3228,28 +3228,20 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {config})                   *nvim_open_win()*
                       `eob` flag of 'fillchars' to a space char, and clearing
                       the |hl-EndOfBuffer| region in 'winhighlight'.
                   • border: Style of (optional) window border. This can either
-                    be a string or an array. The string values are
-                    • "none": No border (default).
-                    • "single": A single line box.
-                    • "double": A double line box.
-                    • "rounded": Like "single", but with rounded corners
-                      ("╭" etc.).
-                    • "solid": Adds padding by a single whitespace cell.
-                    • "shadow": A drop shadow effect by blending with the
-                      background.
-                    • If it is an array, it should have a length of eight or
-                      any divisor of eight. The array will specify the eight
-                      chars building up the border in a clockwise fashion
-                      starting with the top-left corner. As an example, the
-                      double box style could be specified as: >
-                      [ "╔", "═" ,"╗", "║", "╝", "═", "╚", "║" ].
+                    be a string or an array. The string values are the same as
+                    those described in |winborder|. If it is an array, it

comment_data.body:
> comma-separated should be fine `set winborder=╔, ═ ,╗, ║, ╝, ═, ╚, ║ `. Similar to fillchars, it means that the user must declare the field name for each position like `set winborder=topleft:╔, top:═...` or i understand wrong 🤔

Yes that is what I suggested, since a list order may seem arbitrary. The `fillchars` syntax has the disadvantage of being unnecessarily verbose, but it follows an existing precedent so that's a plus imo.

comment_data.body: I think this should be implemented after we support `array/dict` option vlaues. when border is an array it has too many extension possibilities in `nvim_oepn_win`.. currently it is also possible to support all the formats described in `nvim_open_win`, but this may make the code a bit complicated and not very meaningful. If we have an explicit markup in the option value such as =[xx] it may be much easier.  or other smart way which i missed ?

comment_regular_data.body:
> Why not vim.ui.border? option can be updated in did_set through set to take effect immediately.

`vim.ui` is not really for options. Options should be options :)

In general, events and options that fit into the "scopes" (global/buf/win/tab) known by those subsystems, should live in those subsystems. Eventually we should expand those subsystems to support user-defined scopes...

Just a minor nit about the title: There's no terminology like "global-window option", I think you probably meant global-local window options (yeah, I hate the terminology as well). I think just putting "feat(float): add `'winborder'` option" in the title is fine.

If we add this as an option I think it should actually be global-only, and be available as a default style for plugins to use if they want when opening the window.  

the _per window_ option value is redundant with the value in `win_config` which is already per window and has better semantics than window options for window layout related things (The semantics of window options are more for how a buffer is being displayed in a window).
Are there plans to eventually extend this to support custom border characters as well?

@glepnir rebase? This PR (and https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25541 , https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32142 ) is perhaps the most urgent of your existing PRs, imo.

in order of priority:

1. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32142
2. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31074
3. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25541

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(float): add winborder  option
